channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 The New York Times Company

item.title: Can the World Move On Without the U.S.? G20 Leaders Gave It a Shot.
item.description: With the United States boycotting the summit, other nations sought to strike new deals, and some took a tougher tone with President Trump.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.media:description: President Cyril Ramaphosa of South Africa at the opening plenary session of the G20 summit on Saturday.

item.title: Ukraine, U.S. Will Meet About Trump’s Peace Plan to End War With Russia
item.description: President Trump lashed out at Ukraine even as the talks on his peace proposal were still taking place, accusing the country’s leadership of being ungrateful for American support.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd and Nick Cumming-Bruce
item.media:description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio, center, during talks in Geneva on Sunday with Ukrainian officials on a plan to end the war with Russia.

item.title: In Russian-Occupied Mariupol, Everything Ukrainian Must Go
item.description: Russia is remaking Mariupol, which was devastated by a brutal siege in 2022. Ukrainians seeking to move back are finding it hard to recognize the city, or to reclaim their property.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar, Milana Mazaeva and Anna Lukinova
item.media:description: A newly built residential building in Mariupol, in August 2023. The city has undergone drastic changes since the Russian military took the city in 2022.

item.title: How a Sabotaged Ankle Monitor Ended Bolsonaro’s House Arrest
item.description: Shortly before he was expected to start serving a 27-year sentence, Brazil’s former president took a soldering iron to his tracking device.
item.dc:creator: Ana Ionova
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:credit: Federal District’s Secretariat for Penitentiary Administration
item.media:description: The damaged ankle monitor of former President Jair Bolsonaro of Brazil, in a still image taken from a video released by the Federal District’s Secretariat for Penitentiary Administration.

item.title: Denmark Offers Lessons as Europe Toughens Up on Immigration
item.description: Like other European leaders, British Labour politicians are borrowing from Denmark’s restrictive asylum policy. One of its architects cautions that “balance” is necessary.
item.dc:creator: Jeanna Smialek, Amelia Nierenberg and Charlotte de la Fuente
item.media:credit: Charlotte de la Fuente for The New York Times
item.media:description: Voting this past week in Tingbjerg, Denmark. The governing party, which has championed a stricter stance on asylum, performed badly in municipal elections.

item.title: Zelensky Is Under Pressure from Trump and Domestically
item.description: Over nearly four years of wartime leadership, analysts say the Ukrainian leader has repeatedly played weak hands wisely. A U.S. peace plan may be his biggest test.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd and Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine at a French air base this month. He is seeking support from his European partners as he negotiates with the Trump administration over a U.S. peace proposal.

item.title: Fire Threatens Iran’s Ancient Forest, a World Heritage Site
item.description: Iran has been battling its worst drought in more than six decades. A blaze in the north has now eaten through parts of the old treasure.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon and Sanam Mahoozi
item.category: Destruction of Cultural Antiquities and Heritage
item.media:description: A forest in Iran that is part of the Hyrcanian Forests, which are “among the oldest and most biodiverse ecosystems across the globe,” an expert said.

item.title: Israel Says It Assassinated Top Hezbollah Commander in Lebanon
item.description: Escalating its attacks on the Iran-backed militant group in Lebanon, Israel killed Hezbollah’s military chief of staff in an airstrike on an apartment building.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman
item.media:description: Lebanese civil defense workers inspect the damage from an Israeli airstrike on an apartment building in a Dahiya, a suburban area south of Beirut.

item.title: Haitians Rejoice Over Their First World Cup Berth in 50 Years
item.description: The national team’s success in landing a World Cup slot gave Haitians around the world a momentary reprieve from their country’s deep crises.
item.dc:creator: James Wagner
item.media:description: Fans in Port-au-Prince, the capital, celebrated Haiti’s defeat of Nicaragua on Tuesday to qualify for the 2026 FIFA World Cup.

item.title: 20 Killed in Israeli Strikes as Israel and Hamas Trade Blame Over Truce
item.description: Violence has repeatedly flared up in the weeks since a cease-fire was reached, killing hundreds of Palestinians and at least three Israeli soldiers.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman and Saher Alghorra
item.media:description: Rescue workers extinguishing a fire after an Israeli airstrike in western Gaza City on Saturday.

item.title: G20 Leaders Push Back on Trump’s Ukraine Peace Plan
item.description: In a joint statement, the leaders reaffirmed their commitment to Ukraine, which faces the prospect of losing American support if it rejects the latest proposal.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon and Michael Schwirtz
item.media:description: António Costa, president of the European Council, left, and Ursula von der Leyen, president of the European Commission, right, with President Cyril Ramaphosa of South Africa, in Johannesburg on Thursday.

item.title: After Russian Strike on Apartment Buildings, Ukraine’s Hope for Survivors Fades
item.description: Russian missiles hit apartment buildings in Ternopil this week, far from the war’s front line. Dozens of civilians, including children, were killed.
item.dc:creator: Kim Barker, Oleksandra Mykolyshyn and Mauricio Lima

item.title: Trump Claims a White ‘Genocide’ in South Africa. Here’s What’s Really Happening.
item.description: An audacious effort joined two disparate communities, who say they all suffer from the staggering violence and crime affecting the country.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon and Joao Silva
item.media:description: At night in Sonop, a community outside Brits in the North West province of South Africa.

item.title: A Socialist Priest Embraces Venezuela’s Maduro, an Autocratic Leader
item.description: The Rev. Numa Molina, a Jesuit priest, has championed the poor for decades. Now, he is a power broker and a confidant of Venezuela’s embattled president, Nicolás Maduro.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev and Adriana Loureiro Fernandez
item.media:description: People line up to take photos with Father Numa Molina after a Mass in Marizapa, Venezuela.

item.title: Israel Military Commanders Punished Over Hamas Attack Mistakes
item.description: About a dozen people were told they face dismissal or discipline for mistakes tied to the deadly Hamas-led attack that set off the war in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lt. Gen. Eyal Zamir at a ceremony for soldiers and security personnel last month in Jerusalem.

item.title: Denmark’s Migration Model
item.description: The country is getting attention for its tough asylum policies. Can they serve as a bulwark against the far right?
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.media:credit: Charlotte de la Fuente for The New York Times

item.title: The Danish Model for Immigration Crackdown
item.description: For European governments, Denmark’s hard-line immigration policy is a model for how to get a grip on contentious issue and stay in power. Our reporter Jeanna Smialek reports from Copenhagen on the the effects of the policy.
item.dc:creator: Jeanna Smialek, Katrin Bennhold, Nikolay Nikolov, Leila Medina and James Surdam

item.title: Motorcyclist Dies in ‘Globe of Death’ Circus Accident in Italy
item.description: Christián Quezada Vasquez died after losing control during a stunt in which motorcyclists ride around a spherical cage, the circus company said.
item.dc:creator: Ali Watkins
item.media:description: Performers rehearsing inside a “Globe of Death” sphere in Rotterdam, the Netherlands, in 2015. A rider was killed during a similar stunt in Italy last week.

item.title: Titanic Passenger’s Pocket Watch Sells for $2.3 Million
item.description: The watch belonged to Isidor Straus, a co-owner of Macy’s who was traveling first class on the Titanic with his wife when it sank in April 1912.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young

item.title: Democracy Is in Trouble. This Region Is Turning to Its People.
item.description: A small corner of Belgium is recruiting ordinary citizens to help create policies. Participants say it’s renewed their faith in government.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:credit: Valentin Bianchi for The New York Times
item.media:description: People meet to discuss regional policies in Eupen, the capital of the German-speaking region of Ostbelgien in eastern Belgium.

item.title: Texas Men Plotted Coup of Haitian Island to Enslave Women and Children, U.S. Says
item.description: The men, who planned to recruit homeless people for the invasion, took Haitian Creole classes and one enrolled in the U.S. Air Force to prepare for an attack by sailboat, prosecutors said.
item.dc:creator: Rylee Kirk
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: The island of Gonave as seen from Port-au-Prince, Haiti. Two Texas men were indicted in a murder and kidnapping plot that called for staging a coup of the island, federal prosecutors said.

item.title: Jair Bolsonaro Arrested in Brazil Amid Fears He Might Flee to Avoid Prison
item.description: The arrest came days before the former president was expected to be ordered to begin a 27-year prison sentence for staging a failed coup.
item.dc:creator: Ana Ionova
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: Jair Bolsonaro during his house arrest in Brasília on Friday. The former president was arrested the next morning.

item.title: Cannon and Other Artifacts Are Recovered From San José Shipwreck
item.description: Colombian scientists also retrieved three coins and a porcelain cup from the San José, which treasure hunters have come to call the Holy Grail of shipwrecks.
item.dc:creator: Rylee Kirk
item.media:description: A photograph released by the Colombian government shows President Gustavo Petro examining a cannon that was recovered from the wreckage of the San José, a Spanish galleon that sank in 1708.

item.title: Pushing Off
item.description: Thanksgiving’s this coming week. How can we keep a busy holiday season from overwhelming us?
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Are Fighter Jets Canada’s ‘Bargaining Chip’ in Trade Talks?
item.description: Canada began a review of its fighter jet deal with the United States after President Trump imposed tariffs. Now, Sweden is back with a sales pitch for its own jets.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Spencer Colby/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Prime Minister Mark Carney and King Carl XVI Gustaf of Sweden at a state dinner in Ottawa this week. Sweden wants to sell fighter jets manufactured by Saab, a Swedish company, to Canada.

item.title: The Aftermath of a Deadly Strike in Western Ukraine
item.description: At the site of an apartment building in western Ukraine where a Russian strike killed dozens of people, the New York Times reporter Kim Barker heard reactions to a 28-point U.S. proposal to end the war.
item.dc:creator: Kim Barker, Rebecca Suner, Mauricio Lima, Thomas Vollkommer and David Jouppi

item.title: Stopping the Greatest Threat to the Amazon, One Fire at a Time
item.description: After four decades of research, a scientist returns to the Amazon in an effort to change the behavior that has led to years of environmental crisis.
item.dc:creator: David Gelles and Dado Galdieri
item.media:credit: Dado Galdieri for The New York Times

item.title: Germans Are Going Off Beer. That’s Forcing Brewers to Adapt or Go Bust.
item.description: More young people are steering clear of alcohol. The deepening cultural shift has spawned an epidemic of brewery closures.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times

item.title: Russian Exiles See Europe Visa Rule as Blow Against Them, Not Putin
item.description: The European Union said the decision was prompted by sabotage attacks in Europe, but Russians living abroad say Europe is punishing ordinary people.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:credit: Koen Van Weel/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Yulia Navalnaya, widow of the late Russian opposition leader, Alexei Navalny, as she attends the unveiling of a plaque for her late husband, in The Hague, this month.

item.title: What Is Trump’s 28-Point Plan to End Russia’s War in Ukraine?
item.description: President Trump is pressing Kyiv to accept an outcome that yields to President Vladimir V. Putin’s demands.
item.dc:creator: Paul Sonne and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: President Trump has given President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine until Thursday to accept the plan.

item.title: What to Know: Trump Labels Nigeria’s Christian Violence a ‘Genocide’
item.description: There are widespread attacks across the country affecting many religious and ethnic groups. Many of them defy a simple explanation.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Olympia De Maismont/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: At a Catholic Mass in Lagos, Nigeria, in April.

item.title: Cryptology Group Held an Election, but Can’t Decrypt the Results
item.description: A global group of researchers was unable to read the vote tally, after an official lost one of three secret code keys needed to unlock a hyper-secure election system.
item.dc:creator: Pranav Baskar

item.title: 3 Children Are Injured in Grizzly Bear Attack in British Columbia
item.description: The children were among 11 people who were hurt when a grizzly attacked a school group in a remote part of British Columbia, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: Aimee Ortiz and Hannah Ziegler
item.media:credit: Jonathan Hayward/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Grizzly bears in Tweedsmuir Provincial Park near Bella Coola, British Columbia.

item.title: To Many Ukrainians, U.S. Peace Plan Looks Like ‘Capitulation’
item.description: While the White House has cautioned that the proposal is still in “flux,” its contours reflect maximalist demands made by Russia throughout the war that Ukraine has consistently rejected.
item.dc:creator: Maria Varenikova, Oleksandra Mykolyshyn, Oleksandr Chubko, Cassandra Vinograd and Kim Barker
item.media:description: A Ukrainian artillery unit firing at Russian targets in the Zaporizhzhia region, last month.

item.title: As Trump Pushes on Russia-Ukraine Peace Plan, Zelensky’s Options Are Narrowing
item.description: The Ukrainian president’s options are narrowing as he is confronted with a 28-point proposal drafted by American and Russian envoys.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Paul Sonne
item.media:description: The 148th Artillery Brigade preparing to fire at Russian targets in the Zaporizhzhia region of eastern Ukraine in October.

item.title: A Colossal, Hidden Pile of Trash Ignites an Outcry in Britain
item.description: The discovery of a mountain of garbage near a highway is the latest example of what experts say is a growing problem of criminal organizations profiting from illegal dumping.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe
item.media:description: A large pile of illegally dumped waste accumulated next to the River Cherwell near Kidlington, England, on Sunday.

item.title: Former Reform U.K. Politician Sent to Prison for Taking Pro-Russia Bribes
item.description: Nathan Gill was sentenced to 10 and a half years on Friday after admitting he was paid to make pro-Russian speeches in the European Parliament.
item.dc:creator: Lizzie Dearden
item.media:description: Nathan Gill arriving for sentencing at the Old Bailey court in London on Friday.

item.title: At Least 52 Kidnapped From Nigeria School in Second Mass Abduction This Week
item.description: Students and teachers were taken captive from a Catholic school in the latest in a wave of such attacks in the country.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean and Ismail Alfa
item.media:description: Police officers outside a school in Kebbi, Nigeria, where children were kidnapped on Monday. An attack early Friday happened in the neighboring state of Niger.

item.title: Satellite Data Reveals How the U.S. Navy Is Deployed Near Venezuela
item.description: The Times identified nearly 100 locations traversed by naval vessels across a two-and-a-half-month period to determine what the military pressure campaign against Venezuela looks like at sea.
item.dc:creator: Riley Mellen
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: The guided-missile destroyer Gravely leaving a port in Trinidad and Tobago in late October. It is among several U.S. Navy vessels sailing near the coast of Venezuela.

item.title: South Africans Seize on G20 Summit to Air Their Nation’s Ills
item.description: Johannesburg this weekend will host the first G20 meeting on African soil. Protesters are using the moment to draw attention to domestic problems.
item.dc:creator: Zimasa Matiwane
item.media:description: A demonstration on Friday in Johannesburg sought to raise awareness of gender-based violence and femicide.

item.title: European Leaders Back Zelensky After Trump’s Russia-Ukraine Peace Plan Excludes Them
item.description: A U.S.-Russian proposal would require Kyiv to give up territory and reduce its army. If Moscow complies with the terms, it could receive benefits including reintegration into the global economy.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden and Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine in Ankara, Turkey, on Wednesday.

item.title: Roblox Rolls Out Face Scans for Age Verification: What to Know
item.description: The popular gaming platform said the tool was designed to stop children from chatting with older users they didn’t know.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:description: Roblox has begun implementing a new age verification system.

item.title: Japan’s New Leader Mentions Taiwan, and Tanks Her Relationship With China
item.description: Facing reprisals from Beijing for a remark over Taiwan, Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi must walk a fine line to prevent escalating the dispute without looking weak at home.
item.dc:creator: Javier C. Hernández
item.media:credit: Visual China Group, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi of Japan arriving at the venue for the meeting with China’s leader, Xi Jinping, in Gyeongju, South Korea, in October.

item.title: Fine Chocolate in Brazil, Home of the Cacao Bean
item.description: A new generation of craft chocolate makers in Brazil is creating bars with “identity.” And they’re helping to sustain the forest, too.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta and Alessandro Falco

item.title: Sanna Marin Led Finland Through Covid and Russian Threats. But She’s Famous for a Shimmy.
item.description: Sanna Marin was celebrated as a pathbreaking feminist when she became Finland’s prime minister at age 34. Two years after leaving office, she’s trying to turn a scandal over a leaked dancing video into a battle cry.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Blair, Tony, Institute for Global Change
item.media:credit: Juho Kuva for The New York Times
item.media:description: The scandal ultimately gave Sanna Marin more global renown than most Finnish politicians.

item.title: Fátima Bosch of Mexico Wins 2025 Miss Universe Pageant Marred by Scandal
item.description: Fátima Bosch was crowned in Thailand on Friday. The competition got off to a rocky start this month when she briefly walked out after being scolded by an organizer.
item.dc:creator: Francesca Regalado
item.media:description: Mexico's Fátima Bosch was named Miss Universe on Friday.

item.title: Survivors Describe Deadly Snowstorm in Chilean Patagonia
item.description: Five tourists, from Mexico, Britain and Germany, died Monday on a popular hiking trail in the Torres del Paine National Park.
item.dc:creator: Livia Albeck-Ripka and Pascale Bonnefoy
item.category: Torres del Paine National Park (Patagonia, Chile)
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse, via Carabineros de Chile
item.media:description: A picture released by Chile’s Carabineros shows a rescue team at the end of their search and recovery operation for a group of tourists.

item.title: After Syria’s 14-Year Civil War, a Search for Victims Leads to Mass Graves
item.description: More than 100,000 people disappeared during the civil war. To bring closure to some of their families, the new government faces the challenging task of exhuming remains from scores of burial sites.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: A trench at the Najha cemetery near Damascus, Syria. The area is believed to hold a mass grave.

item.title: Researcher’s Smuggling Arrest Casts Light on Dispute Over Chinese Students
item.description: As some lawmakers press U.S. universities to curtail ties with China, a postdoctoral student’s prosecution raises questions about how big the danger actually is.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni

item.title: Australia Adds Twitch to Social Media Ban for Teens
item.description: Twitch, a livestreaming service popular with gamers, joins nine other platforms that will be required to remove Australian users under the age of 16.
item.dc:creator: Francesca Regalado
item.media:description: The ban will take effect on Dec. 10, about a year after Parliament passed one of the world’s most comprehensive measures to protect children and teenagers from potential harm on the internet.

item.title: Hundreds of Invasive Goldfish to Be Culled From Ottawa Pond
item.description: Thousands washed ashore dead in the spring, but the fish are back. “They’re pretty hard to kill,” a biology professor said.
item.dc:creator: Rylee Kirk

item.title: U.S. Ambassador to Canada Channels Harsh Trump Tone
item.description: Pete Hoekstra’s bluntness is seen as undiplomatic by Canadian officials and interpreted as a way for the Trump administration to turn up the heat as trade talks drag on.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:credit: Jeff Mcintosh/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Pete Hoekstra, the American ambassador to Canada, speaking in Banff, Alberta, in September.

item.title: The Privacy Battle in Our Brains
item.description: My colleague talks about technology that can actually read our minds — and maybe even change them.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Brain Initiative/Activity Map Project (US Health and Human Services)
item.media:credit: Daniel Lozada for The New York Times

item.title: Nigerian Student Describes Hiding From Kidnappers at School
item.description: The girl hid in a toilet; another managed to sneak away. Security forces are still trying to rescue the 24 girls who were abducted in northwestern Nigeria.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean and Ismail Auwal
item.media:description: The dormitory where gunmen kidnapped 24 girls in Kebbi, Nigeria, on Monday.

item.title: Want to Immigrate to the UK? The Government Says You Must Earn It.
item.description: The government plans to double the period needed for many legal immigrants to become permanent residents, while cutting it for higher-rate taxpayers.
item.dc:creator: Lizzie Dearden
item.media:description: A proposal on Thursday was the latest of many from the government of Prime Minister Keir Starmer aimed at showcasing a tougher approach on immigration.

item.title: Miss Universe 2025: What Time and How to Watch Live
item.description: A winner will be crowned after two weeks of competition marred by controversy.
item.dc:creator: Francesca Regalado
item.media:description: Contestants presenting national costumes during the 74th Miss Universe pageant in Bangkok on Wednesday.

item.title: U.S. Ran a War Game on Ousting Maduro. Venezuela Fell Into Chaos.
item.description: An official U.S. government exercise during President Trump’s first term forecast turmoil and potential violence in a post-Maduro Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of a group loyal to President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela, during a rally in Caracas in September.

item.title: At Saudi Behest, Trump Vows to Seek Peace in Sudan, a Goal He Had Spurned
item.description: It is unclear what President Trump will do to end a brutal civil war in which both sides are backed by U.S. allies, but his statement that he will try has raised hopes for peace.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh and Vivian Nereim
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: After the Sudanese military retook part of Khartoum from the Rapid Support Forces, the military section capital’s airport in was strewed with plane wreckage in March.

item.title: Trump to Send U.S. Official to G20 in South Africa After All
item.description: The South African president suggested Washington had decided to participate in the summit, despite an earlier claim of a boycott.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:description: A billboard of G20 leaders in Johannesburg on Wednesday. A senior Trump administration official said the United States’ participation would be purely ceremonial.
